message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, the medication is most likely a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), which is frequently used as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. The most frequently encountered side effects of SSRIs include anorgasmia (difficulty reaching orgasm), insomnia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are potential side effects of antidepressant medications, but they are not specific to SSRIs and are more commonly associated with tricyclic antidepressants and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), and among the options, Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line medications for treating MDD. The most frequently encountered side effects of SSRIs are anorgasmia and insomnia. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are possible side effects of antidepressants, but these are not the most common side effects of SSRIs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis is Major Depressive Disorder, and the first-line medication is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI). Anorgasmia and insomnia are some of the most frequently encountered side effects of SSRIs. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are more commonly associated with the use of antidepressants in patients with Bipolar Disorder, which is not mentioned in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most likely diagnosis is major depressive disorder, for which a first-line medication is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Common side effects of SSRIs include anorgasmia (inability to achieve orgasm), insomnia, nausea, and headache. While hypomania and suicidal thoughts are possible side effects of antidepressants, they are not the most frequently encountered ones for SSRIs. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) and tricyclic antidepressants are also used to treat depression but are considered second- or third-line options due to their more significant side effect profiles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of consistent sadness, worthlessness, anxiety, and anhedonia suggest depression. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line medications used to treat this disorder. Common side effects include anorgasmia and insomnia. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are possible side effects of antidepressant medications, but are not the most frequently encountered.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has major depressive disorder. The first-line medication for this disorder is Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). The most frequently encountered side effects of SSRI are anorgasmia and insomnia. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are possible side effects but less commonly encountered.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest major depressive disorder, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a first-line treatment. Anorgasmia and insomnia are common side effects of SSRIs, while hypomania and suicidal thoughts are potential but less frequent side effects. Option C is incorrect because monoamine oxidase inhibitors are not a first-line treatment and have more serious potential side effects such as hypertensive crisis. Tricyclic antidepressants also have potential side effects such as dry mouth and constipation, but hypomania and suicidal thoughts are less common than with SSRIs.

The most common side effects of SSRIs are anorgasmia and insomnia. Hypomania and suicidal thoughts are possible side effects, but they are less common. Tricyclic antidepressants are also not considered first-line treatment, and they have a higher risk of hypomania and suicidal thoughts as side effects.
